review.title: Domain Filtering Consistencies
review.abstract: Enforcing local consistencies is one of the main features of constraint reasoning. Which level of local consistency should be used when searching for solutions in a constraint network is a basic question. Arc consistency and partial forms of arc consistency have been widely studied, and have been known for sometime through the forward checking or the MAC search algorithms. Until recently, stronger forms of local consistency remained limited to those that change the structure of the constraint graph, and thus, could not be used in practice, especially on large networks. This paper focuses on the local consistencies that are stronger than arc consistency, without changing the structure of the network, i.e., only removing inconsistent values from the domains. In the last five years, several such local consistencies have been proposed by us or by others. We make an overview of all of them, and highlight some relations between them. We compare them both theoretically and experimentally, considering their pruning efficiency and the time required to enforce them.

sections.text: Enforcing local consistency is one of the main features of the constraint argument. What level of local consistency should be used in the search for solutions in a constraint network is a fundamental question. Arc consistency and partial forms of constraint consistency have been extensively studied and have been known for some time through forward checking or MAC search algorithms. Until recently, stronger forms of local consistency were limited to those that change the structure of the constraint graph, and therefore could not be used in practice, especially in large networks. This paper focuses on local consistencies that are stronger than the constraint consistency without changing the structure of the network, i.e., removing only inconsistent values from the domains. In the past five years, several such local consistencies have been proposed by us or others.

sections.heading: 6.1.1 Results on problems on which all the studied local consistencies hold
sections.text: (see Table 2) If all the local consistencies studied stick to a constraint network, all the corresponding ltering algorithms are useless; they waste time checking whether the local consistencies hold without erasing an inconsistent value. The stronger the local consistency, the more important is the time wasted. We see the consequences of the exponential worst-case time complexity of NIC1. For most of these problems, NIC1 requires a reasonable CPU time. But, as we can see in problem Scen11, a combinatorial explosion can result in a truly prohibitive CPU time for NIC1.

sections.heading: 6.1.2 Results on arc inconsistent problems (cf. Table 3)
sections.text: When arc consistency is needed to detect the inconsistency of the problem, stronger local consistencies are not always more costly. Figure 3 shows that Max-RPC1 often has the best cpu-time performance, and in Graph06, for example, AC7 is one of the most expensive local consistencies. In enforcing AC, which requires the arc inconsistency of the problem to spread, stronger local consistency can erase a domain faster than AC7. In these constraint networks, all the algorithms used have a very low cpu time requirement, except for NIC1, which can be very expensive in some cases, such as Scen08.

sections.heading: 6.1.3 Results on the other problems (cf. Table 4)
sections.text: For many of the RLFAP problems, local consistencies do not erase the same sets of inconsistent values. We can see an important similarity between the pruning, especially for the problems ScenXX.1 and GraphXX.1.Obviously, for most of these problems, the more pruned the local consistency is, the more important the time it takes. We can see this, for example, in the problems Scen06.1 and Scen09.1. However, AC7, RPC2, PIC2 and Max-RPC1 have CPU time performances of the same magnitude, while SAC1, SRPC1 and NIC1 are often much more elaborate. Domain Filtering ConsistenciesThis is particularly evident for Graph04 and Graph10. However, it is di cult to say which is the most interesting local consistency in these problems.

sections.heading: 6.2 Randomly Generated Problems
sections.text: The random uniform CN generator in Section 5.2 is used to compare the CPU time required to enforce local consistency. We must point out that NIC is not designed to be used on uniform CNs, but to adjust the degree of variables in the constraint diagram. So NIC would perform better on non-uniform CNs than the ones shown in this section. The problems generated have 200 variables and 30 values in each initial domain. Figure 8 shows the results on CNs with a density of.02. These CNs are relatively sparse, as the variables have on average four neighbors. Figure 9 presents the performance at density. 15 (the variables have an average of 30 neighbors). Due to the parameters, there are no feared variables (MacIntyre, Prosser, Smith, & Walsh, 1998) in the problems generated.

sections.heading: 6.3 Experiments on Sparse CNs
sections.text: Even on sparse CNs (see Figure 8), the CPU time results between algorithms (7h 48min for strong PCs at their peak, when AC7 requires an average of 0.22 seconds on average) are so low that a logarithmic scale must be used. Strong PC is really prohibitive, even for 6. In Section 5.2, the density reaching 1, there were obviously frightened variables for some parameter sets. Debruyne & Bessi discuss density values. SRPC and SAC have bad CPU time to the number of deleted values, except SAC on CNs, which have very narrow limitations, because the SAC algorithm used is based on AC6, which can be more precise than AC7 for such problems. On these sparse CNs, NIC often has better CPU time to the number of deleted values than SAC, but it removes no more values than RICs. Consequently, NCU has a bad PU time to the number of two SICs, although the number of SIC are stronger.

sections.heading: 6.4 Experiments on more Dense CNs
sections.text: On denser CNs (see Figure 9), the complexity peaks of AC7, RPC2, PIC2, and MaxRPC remain close together. PIC2 is less worthwhile because it clears few additional values compared to RPC2, while the CPU time requirements are close to those of Max-RPC. MaxRPC has one of the best CPU time to number of deleted value ratios. Once RPC leads to a domain, the CPU time performances of SRPC and RPC2 merge. In fact, the SRPC algorithm used forces RPC2 before stopping the limited path consistency of the sub-problems P jDi = fagfor each (i; a) 2 D. When all values of a domain are inconsistent, RPC preprocessing nds is the global inconsistency of the problem and the SRPC algorithm.

sections.heading: 6.5 Discussion
sections.text: This year, it has come to the point that it will only be once before there is such a process, in which there is such a process.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusion
sections.text: We proposed a new class of local consistencies, singleton consistencies. We examined these new local consistencies and the other local consistencies that can be used equally on large CNs, removing more values than arc consistency. We showed some correlations between them and compared their intersection and time consistencies both theoretically and experimentally. Most incisive are neighborhood consistency and singleton consistency. However, SRPC is time-consuming and the exponential time complexity of NIC makes it unusable on dense CNs. If we are looking for a local consistency that would be beneficial during the search, RPC and Max RPC seem to be the most promising local consistencies. In fact, they are relatively inexpensive and far cheaper than arc consistency.

sections.heading: 8. Acknowledgements
sections.text: We would like to thank Toby Walsh for his suggestions to improve the presentation of the contributions in section 5.

referenceMentions.context: Finding a solution in a constraint network involves looking for a set of value assignments, one for each variable, so that all the constraints are simultaneously satis ed (Meseguer, 1989; Tsang, 1993).
We also show a property of path inverse consistency that can be used to have an optimal worst case time complexity in a path inverse consistency algorithm (Debruyne, 2000).
PC5 (Singh, 1995) O(n 3 d 3 ) ( ) O(n 3 d 2 ) PC8 (Chmeiss & J egou, 1996) O(n 3 d 4 ) O(n 2 d) 2
PIC2 (Debruyne, 2000) O(en+ ed 2 + cd 3 ) ( ) O(ed+ cd)
As shown in (Debruyne, 2000), if we assume that the constraint network is arc consistent, enforcing PIC requires checking even less 3-tuples than those mentioned in (Freuder & Elfe, 1996).

The algorithms used are AC7 (Bessi ere, Freuder, & R egin, 1995), RPC2 (Debruyne & Bessi ere, 1997a), PIC2 (Debruyne, 2000), Max-RPC1 (Debruyne & Bessi ere, 1997a), the singleton arc consistency algorithm of (Debruyne & Bessi ere, 1997b) (SAC1) based on AC6, a SRPC algorithm based on RPC2 (SRPC1), and the NIC algorithm proposed in (Freuder & Elfe, 1996) (NIC1) using FCCBJ (Prosser, 1993) (as inFreuder & Elfe, 1996) with dom+deg dynamic variable ordering heuristic (minimal domain rst, in which ties are broken by choosing the variable with the highest degree in the constraint graph Frost & Dechter, 1995; Bessi ere & R egin, 1996).

The algorithms used are AC7 (Bessi ere, Freuder, & R egin, 1995), RPC2 (Debruyne & Bessi ere, 1997a), PIC2 (Debruyne, 2000), Max-RPC1 (Debruyne & Bessi ere, 1997a), the singleton arc consistency algorithm of (Debruyne & Bessi ere, 1997b) (SAC1) based on AC6, a SRPC algorithm based on RPC2 (SRPC1), and the NIC algorithm proposed in (Freuder & Elfe, 1996) (NIC1) using FCCBJ (Prosser, 1993) (as inFreuder & Elfe, 1996) with dom+deg dynamic variable ordering heuristic (minimal domain rst, in which ties are broken by choosing the variable with the highest degree in the constraint graph Frost & Dechter, 1995; Bessi ere & R egin, 1996).
The results of these experiments (Debruyne, 1999) show that Quick has better cpu time performances than MAC on large and hard randomly generated CNs that are relatively sparse.

metadata.abstractText: Enforcing local consistencies is one of the main features of constraint reasoning. Which level of local consistency should be used when searching for solutions in a constraint network is a basic question. Arc consistency and partial forms of arc consistency have been widely studied, and have been known for sometime through the forward checking or the MAC search algorithms. Until recently, stronger forms of local consistency remained limited to those that change the structure of the constraint graph, and thus, could not be used in practice, especially on large networks. This paper focuses on the local consistencies that are stronger than arc consistency, without changing the structure of the network, i.e., only removing inconsistent values from the domains. In the last ve years, several such local consistencies have been proposed by us or by others. We make an overview of all of them, and highlight some relations between them. We compare them both theoretically and experimentally, considering their pruning e ciency and the time required to enforce them.
